user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_destroy(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    status = pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.

Reasons (why other fragments do not need investigation):
- The function parameter is already a pointer to const: const OS_object_token_t *token — this matches the rule.
- The use of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token) ultimately passes &(*token) to OS_ObjectIndexFromToken which accepts a const OS_object_token_t *; there is no loss of const-qualification or unsafe conversion here.
- The impl variable is a pointer to OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t and points into the mutable OS_impl_condvar_table array. It cannot be const-qualified because the code obtains addresses of impl->cv and impl->mut and passes them to pthread_cond_destroy / pthread_mutex_destroy, which require pointers to non-const objects (the operations mutate/destroy those objects). Making impl a pointer-to-const would prevent these required operations.
- The addresses &impl->cv and &impl->mut are pointers to the actual pthread types; these must remain non-const to satisfy the pthread API, so they are not candidates for const-qualification.

Given the above, there are no pointers in this function that could be more const-qualified without breaking required behavior or API contracts, so no fragments need further investigation for Rule 8.13.
